� General Information
Every constant NC_xxx_CONF describes whether a system is equipped with additional functionality or not.
? Sensor-Con?guration
For all sensors (NC_xxx_CONF) following possibilities are available:
0 = NO_SENSOR: sensor is not available, value never used
1 = SENSOR_ALWAYS_USED: sensor is always available and value is used
2 = SENSOR_SWITCHABLE: sensor-evaluation can be switched "on / off "during runtime (by LC_switch)

CHRG, CHRG Con?guration data
Data Value
NC_CHRG_CONF 0 = no charger
1 = turbocharger
2 = supercharger
LC_TCHA_CONF Calibration switch
0 = naturally aspirated engine
1 = turbocharger
NC_SYM_BAS_ERR_CONF 0 = symptom based ERRM is not implemented
1 = symptom based ERRM is implemented
NC_RCL_CONF 0 = no RCL functionality included
1 = RCL functionality included
Local con?guration data
Here the con?guration data are listed, which are used only in the CHRG aggregate.
? Number of turbo chargers (mono / bi turbo)
NC_NR_TCHA Number of turbo chargers
1 = one turbo charger - Mono turbo system
2 = two turbo chargers ? Bi turbo system
Recirculation-system (RCL) - location: intake path
NC_RCL_UP_ICO position of recirculation pipe inlet
0 = downstream intercooler
1 = upstream intercooler
General:
NC_CHRG_CONF = 1
NC_NR_TCHA = 1
NC_RCL_UP_ICO = 1
NC_SYM_BAS_ERR_CONF = 1
NC_MAF_CHA_DIF= 1
NC_RCL_CONF = 1

� General Information
Air temperatures upstream and downstream the turbocharger compressor are calculated here.
With C_STATE_TIA_CMPR_CLC the calculation direction of TIA_CHA_UP and TIA_CHA_DOWN can be chosen.
Possible values are
- 0 calculate TIA_CHA_UP based on TAM, calculate TIA_CHA_DOWN based on TIA_CHA_UP
- 1 calculate TIA_CHA_UP based on TAM, calculate TIA_CHA_DOWN based on TIA_THR
- 2 calculate TIA_CHA_UP based on TIA_CHA_DOWN, calculate TIA_CHA_DOWN based on TIA_THR
If the TAM signal is for sure unreliable (STATE_TAM_N_TCHA = 0) then LC_TAM_N_TCHA_TIA_THR determines
whether TIA_CHA_UP and TIA_CHA_DOWN are calculated based on TIA_THR (=1) or based on a ?x substitute
value (=0).
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF==1
Deactivation: if activation not true

10.2.2.1.2.1 Calculate TIA_CHA_UP based on TAM
As long as there is a reliable ambient temperature signal TAM, temperature upstream turbocharger compres-
sor TIA_CHA_UP is calculated based on TAM with a correction IP_TIA_AIC_DOWN_OFS which describes the
warming up of the air in?uenced by mass air ?ow and the difference between intake manifold and ambient
temperature (FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE = 0).
If TAM is certainly unreliable, e.g. if all temperature sensors have failed (FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE = 1), then
TIA_CHA_UP is set to a high constant substitute value of 50 degree Celsius, which is for sure higher than
any real temperature upstream turbocharger compressor at steady turbocharged operation. If TIA_CHA_UP
is estimated too high, than also turbocharger speed N_TCHA will be estimated too high, thus protecting the
turbocharger from actual overspeed.
T_TAM_N_TCHA is the time elapsed since the most recent update of TAM. If TAM has not been updated for a
long time, i.e. STATE_TAM_N_TCHA <2 for C_T_TAM_N_TCHA, then FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE is ramped 0 to 1
within approximately half a minute, thus fading TIA_CHA_UP to the save substitute value 50 degree Celsius.

T_TAM_N_TCHA is the time elapsed since the most recent update of TAM. If TAM has not been updated for a
long time, i.e. STATE_TAM_N_TCHA <2 for C_T_TAM_N_TCHA, then FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE is ramped 0 to 1
within approximately half a minute, thus fading TIA_CHA_UP to the save substitute value 50 degree Celsius.
When TAM is updated again after a long time without update, T_TAM_N_TCHA is reset to 0 and FAC_TAM_
N_TCHA_SAVE is ramped 1 - >0 within approximately half a minute, thus fading TIA_CHA_UP from the save
substitute value 50 �C to the normal TAM based calculation result.

10.5.2.1 Calculation of turbocharger compressor mass ?ow and volume ?ow
Compressor air mass ?ow MAF_KGH_CMPR can be calculated either
- based on throttle air mass ?ow MAF_KGH_THR_TCHA with a correction MAF_KGH_CMPR_OFS_THR based
on the boost pressure gradient (LC_MAF_KGH_CMPR_THR = 1), this calculation path is mandatory for systems
without air mass ?ow sensor, or
- based on air ?lter air mass ?ow MAF_KGH_AIC_TCHA (LC_MAF_KGH_CMPR_THR = 0), this calculation may be
used for systems with air mass ?ow sensor.

CHRG, Basic boost pressure adaptation (Appl. Inc.)
� Function Description
10.6.1 Inhibition condition
Basic boost pressure adaptation can be inhibited
- in case of boost pressure actuator trouble
- in case of too high exhaust gas temperature relatively to
reference conditions
- in case of unavailable boost pressure sensor
- in case of unreliable ambient air temperature or
- via FARM.
// Inhibition in case boost pressure actuator trouble
LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP =
(STATE_BPA != ?OPM? and STATE_BPA != ?AD? and LC_IDX_BPA_SWI == 1)
// Inhibition in case too big exhaust gas temperature difference
// compared to reference conditions
LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP = LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP or
(TEG_TUR_UP - TEG_REF_POW_TCHA_MIN > C_TEG_TUR_UP_DIF_MAX_AD)
// Inhibition in case of unavailable pressure upstream throttle sensor
LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP = LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP or
(NOT LV_ENA_PUT)
// Inhibition in case of unreliable ambient air temperature
LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP = LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP or
(STATE_TAM_N_TCHA < C_STATE_TAM_N_TCHA_MIN)
// Inhibition by FARM
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission
(NC_FID_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD, LV_PRMS_TMP)
LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD =
LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_TMP or (NOT LV_PRMS_TMP)

� General Information
Basic boost pressure is de?ned as the pressure upstream throttle occuring when
- the throttle is wide open (i.e. opened as de?ned by TPS_SP_MDL_MAX)
- the turbocharger turbine is controlled to produce minimum turbocharger power by
- fully opening the wastegate - if possible - or at least controlling the wastate to be open respectively, or
- fully opening the vans of a variable geometry turbine.
Its value mainly depends on engine speed, with in?uences of exhaust gas temperature and intake temperature.
Engine individual tolerances are learnt in module Basic boost pressure adaptation and are coordinated here.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF == 1
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 10MS

� General Information
Basic boost pressure PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN is de?ned as the stationary pressure upstream throttle if the throttle
is completely open and the turbocharger is controlled to deliver minimum power. This basic boost pressure
varies between individual engines. These variations are learnt in this module and stored in adaptive maps.

CHRG, Basic boost pressure adaptation
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF == 1 and LV_ST_END == 1
Deactivation: otherwise
Recurrence: 10 ms
� Function Description
10.8.1 activation conditions for adaptation
If (1) LV_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD_DIAG_ACK == 1 then
// reset auxiliary error symptoms after acknowledgement from diagnosis
LV_SYM_PUT_WG_OPEN_DIAG_L = 0
LV_SYM_PUT_WG_OPEN_DIAG_H = 0
endif (1)
// low pass filtered boost pressure control deviation
PUT_DIF_MMV_PUT_WG_OPEN_ADn =
PUT_DIF_MMV_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD + C_CRLC_PUT_DIF_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD*
(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL - PUT_DIF_MMV_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD)
// activation conditions
if (2) (
// adaptation in PQ and FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL window
(FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL >= C_FAC_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_MIN
and FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL < C_FAC_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_MAX
and MAP > PUT * C_PQ_THD_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD
and abs(PUT_DIF_MMV_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD) < C_PUT_DIF_MAX_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD)
or
// force increasing adaptation because despite of minimum
// turbocharger control current PUT > learnt basic boost pressure
(LV_FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL_BOL == 1 and
PUT > PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN + C_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_THD_POS)
or
// force decreasing adaptation because despite of wide open throttle
// current PUT < learnt basic boost pressure
(PQ_SP_TCHA > C_PQ_SP_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD and
PUT < PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN + C_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_THD_NEG)
)
and LV_INH_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD == 0
then(2)
T_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD = T_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD - 10 ms
else (2)
// reset delay timer
T_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD = C_T_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_INI
LV_CDN_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD = 0
endif (2)
// A first adaptation step is done when the adaptation conditions have
// been fulfilled for
if (3) T_DLY_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD == 0 // delay time has elapsed
then (3)
LV_CDN_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD = 1 // TRIGGER for adaptation algorithm
// reset delay timer
T_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD = C_T_PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN_AD_INI_REP
else (3)

map IP_FAC_POW_CHA_1 or implicit compressor ef?ciency map IP_FAC_EFF_CMPR_MDL.

10.9.2.2.1.1 Compressor power factor calculation - map based
Map alignment factor C_N_CHA_COR_REF_VOL_FLOW transforms the second input of IP_FAC_POW_CHA_1 to min-
imize interpolation errors. C_N_CHA_COR_REF_VOL_FLOW must be calibrated equal to or smaller than the
smallest N_TCHA breakpoint of IP_FAC_POW_CHA_1, because quotient C_N_CHA_COR_REF_VOL_FLOW / PRM_
N_TCHA_STND is limited to <1.

CHRG, Boost pressure limits
10.11.2.1.2 Calculation of maximum permissible boost pressure resulting from maximum turbocharger speed.
In coordinates of the turbocharger compressor map the intersection of the line of maximum turbocharger
speed and the volumetric ef?ciency line is calculated.
Reduced turbocharger copmpressor volume ?ow is normalized with its maximum value C_FLOW_VOL_CHA_
UP_RED_MAX.
The line of maximum turbocharger speed is represented by a cubic approximation with the 4 coef?cients in
ID_FAC_PQ_FLOW_VOL_N_TCHA_MAX [1-3] (1 - absolute, 2 - linear, 3 - quadratic, 4 - cubic coef?cient).
FLOW_VOL_CHA_UP_REL_PUT_MAX is the normalized ?ow of the intersection point, PQ_CHA_PUT_MAX is the
corresponding pressure ratio.
The maximum permissible boost pressure resulting from turbocharger speed limitation ist PUT_MAX_N_TCHA_
MAX.

// Adaptation of CHRG inputs to project environment

POW_CHA[0] = POW_CHA_MV

FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL = IP_FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL (POSN_SP_BPA_RGL[0])
else

endif
// Adaptation from/to old interfaces

PQ_SP_TCHA = PQ_THR_SP

// Turbocharger turbine control adaptation is inhibited
// - via FARM or
// - in an engine speed window [C_N_MIN_xx, C_N_MAX_xx]
// in one valve lift chosen by LC_INH_PUT_AD_VVL
if (N > C_N_MIN_INH_PUT_AD_VVL) and
(N < C_N_MAX_INH_PUT_AD_VVL) then
LV_INH_PUT_AD_TMP = LC_INH_PUT_AD_VVL xor LV_STATE_VVL_TCHA

for i = 1 to 4
if N_32 >= C_N_MIN_PUT_AD(i) and N_32 <= C_N_MAX_PUT_AD(i) and

TQI_REQ_SLOW <= C_TQI_REQ_FAST_MAX_PUT_AD(i) then

sgn(FAC_PUT_AD_ADD) * 0.000061 (1hex)
endif

10.13.2 Operate 10 ms recurrence
The regular pressure upstream throttle setpoint is low passed ?ltered in case of torque limitation for turbo
charger protection. In case of limitation of the turbo charger speed setpoint, the pressure upstream throttle is
decremented to reach the limited turbo charger speed. The result may be overwritten by a manual value.
10.13.2.1 Calculation of Regular pressure upstream throttle set point
The regular pressure upstream throttle setpoint is de?ned based on MAP_SP and N in IP_PUT_SP. Maximum
PUT_SP is de?ned by the upper breakpoint of IP_PUT_SP.
In case of "Best response" the maximum of regular and PUT_SP_OPTM_RESP is taken.

10.13.2.4 Calculation of PUT_SP for N_TCHA_MAX_SP

the desired, PUT_SP is moving around the limited setpoint.

� Function Description
10.14.1 Initialization to neutral values
Initatilization of PUT_SP_TOL to maximum and all other variables to 0.
10.14.2 CHRG_DEFSPPUTAI0/OPM
10.14.2.1 Calculation of boost pressure setpoint limits
Boost pressure setpoint top limit PUT_SP_TOL takes into account
- a limitation by compressor surge line IP_PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL,
- a limitation due to high air temperature IP_PQ_CHA_MAX
- a limitation in case of ambient pressure sensor failure C_FAC_PQ_CHA_SURGE_PUT_SP_TOL
- turbocharger speed limits coordinated in PUT_MAX_TCHA_PROT.
- boost limitation at standing car without driver request outside End of line tests

10.14.2.3 Calculation of boost pressure setpoint variables for best response operation
Boost pressure setpoint for best response PUT_SP_OPTM_RESP is a boost pressure setpoint actively increased
above MAP_SP to keep the turbocharger spinning at high speed
- for race start, separately for 2 and 4 wheel drive variants or
- for normal driving, separately for sport and economy mode with an ambient pressure dependent basis.
When best response mode is active an auxiliary FARM input is set.

� General Information
This module calculates the conditions at the charger, the intercooler and the air cleaner at the desired set-
point.
In this 1st step it is assumed that the recirculation path will be closed when the charge air pressure control
is active. Therefore the mass air ?ow through air cleaner, charger intercooler and engine at the set point are
equal.

� General Information
Indicated torque setpoint limitations for turbocharger protection are coordinated here. This includes limita-
tions because of normal operation at system limits (e.g. turbocharger speed, air temperature, surge limit) and
limitations because of recognized component failures (e.g. recirculation valve, leakage, sensors)
In case those torque reductions do not show the wanted effect, there are constants for absolute maximum (not
applied in case of RCL failure) which cause an immediate complete opening of the wastegate or an immediate
torque setpoint reduction.
Decreasing the torque setpoint is also appropriate solution if a failure is detected on the wastegate or on the
recirculation valve (remark: for the recirculation valve, it is necessary to decrease torque only if RCL close
failure state is detected)

10.16.2 Operation at 10ms recurrence
LV_TCHA_PROT_ACT coordinates errors for turbocharger deactivation.
10.16.2.1 Calculation of STATE_TCHA_PROT
STATE_TCHA_PROT collects all the information about limited turbo charger performance because of extreme
operating conditions. Each limit corresponds to one bit of STATE_TCHA_PROT:
Bit 14= 16384 = Permanent torque limitation because of too high exhaust gas temperature
Bit 13= 8192 = Permanent torque limitation because of boost pressure actuator related error
Bit 11= 2048 = Permanent torque limitation because of too high charger speed
Bit 10= 1024 = Permanent torque limitation because of error via FARM

LC_PRS_N_GB_MIN_TCHA_SWI V 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Switch between local and global environment inputs for N_GB_MIN_TCHA calculation
� General Information
Calculation of minimum engine speed without turbocharger compressor surge after gear shift
When an automatic transmission shifts to a higher gear while in boost engine operation, the operation point
of the compressor shifts to higher pressure ratio at nearly constant volume ?ow. During this transition the
compressor operating point may cross the surge line, and surge may occur. At gear shift to a higher gear at
nearly constant torque and vehicle speed engine speed decreases.
In order to prevent surge, the present module stores in IP_N_GB_MIN_TCHA for every transmission type STATE_
TRANS_TYP_AT the minimum engine speed N_GB_MIN_TCHA , the engine speed N may fall to after gear shift,
so that surge will not occur.
Via LC_PRS_N_GB_MIN_TCHA_SWI can be chosen, whether the local pressure ratio PQ_CHA_MV and air tem-
perature TIA_CHA_UP at the turbocharger compressor (= 1) or the global temperature TAM and pressures AMP
and PUT (= 0) are used as map inputs.

high throttle position gradients (if cruise control active) to avoid a delay of the boost pressure increase.

10.18.1.6 Coordination of RCL opening request
When the application sets LC_RCL_OPEN_PU_SUPP = 1, then the below description is not relevant.
When the application sets LC_RCL_OPEN_PU_SUPP to zero, then in the normal operation, it is wished to have
the recirculation valve open in the PU and PUC engine state. However, for the diagnosis of the recirculation
valve to be done in the PUC phase, it should be ensured that only for this diagnosis phase (only when the PUT
controller in static operation gives anomaly values), that until the diagnosis ends the recirculation valve shall
be closed in the PUC and PU engine state. This is done using the extra AND condition based on LV_N_TCHA_
MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_RCL and LV_CTR_RCL_OPEN_MAX.

CHRG, Recirculation actuator setpoint determination
If in stationary conditions it is detected that the PUT controller has a higher value than it should be, then
leakage before the throttle, or a stuck open recirculation valve, or even a stuck waste gate could be responsible
for the behaviour. To differentiate and diagnose which component is responsible, the turbocharger plausibility
diagnosis looks for the closed loop controller value.
When it is detected from the Turbocharger plausibility diagnosis, that there was a turbocharger speed reduc-
tion, the bit LV_N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_RCL is set. This bit is then used during the PUC engine state in
this module, to set the recirculation valve position to open and close at regular intervals. After a calibratable
delay, the period of time for opening and period of time for closing shall be given through C_T_PER_OPEN_RCL
and C_T_PER_CLOSE_RCL. The number of times the periodic opening shall happen is limited through C_CTR_
RCL_OPEN_DIAG_MAX. The LV_RCL_DIAG_OPEN_ACT bit is set when the conditions for the periodic opening
of the recirculation valve are ful?lled. Once the maximum number of cycles are reached, the bit LV_CTR_RCL_
OPEN_MAX is set and the recirculation valve operates in the normal condition. It is recommended, that the
C_T_PER_OPEN_RCL and C_T_PER_CLOSE_RCL should be calibrated with a smaller value so that, the integral
calculation is still plausible.

CHRG, Boost pressure control
by modifying the turbine actuator precontrol coming from the inverse turbocharger model chain. When in
charged engine operation the throttle is fully opened this boost pressure controller deviation determines the
correspondence of MAF and MAF_STK_SP_TCHA as well as TQI and TQI_SP accordingly.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF
Deactivation: !LC_TCHA_CONF
Recurrence: 10MS, SEG
� Function Description
10.20.1 Initialization
10.20.1.1 Initialization to neutral values
10.20.2 OPM
The whole function is executed every 10ms for low engine speed (N <C_N_MIN_PUT_CTL_SEG) and segment
synchronously for high engine speed (N >= C_N_MIN_PUT_CTL_SEG).
10.20.2.1 Function task
The boost pressure controller is active if not deactivated
- by deactivated throttle LV_MTC_CUR_OFF
- during engine start
- by inhibition bit coming from Application incidence.
If LV_PUT_CTL_ACT is deactivated, the closed loop value is set to zero.
The I share of the PUT controller is activated only when both the general charge air pressure controller activa-
tion conditions are ful?lled and when PUT is greater than the basic charge pressure PUT_WG_OPEN.
If LV_PUT_CTL_I_ACT (I-share activation of the controller) is deactivated its closed loop value is ramped to
zero.
10.20.2.1.1 Boost pressure controller I share forgetting factor
The forgetting factor FAC_LPF_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I for the boost pressure controller I share is calculated here
based on the operating point dynamics. For the time step of a valve lift change a separate forgetting factor
C_FAC_LPF_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_VLFT is valid.

� General Information
This module calculates the PUT controller values FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL and FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_
RGL. This module has to be calculated before the Charge air pressure control.
The calibration values of IP_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D / _I are 8 bit, but the interpolation is done in 16 bit.

SEG if (N >= C_N_MIN_PUT_CTL_SEG)

10.21.2 Operate(10ms):
10.21.2.1 Calculation of output variables for CHRG
PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL_TMP = PUT_SP - PUT
PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL(n) = PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL(n-1) + IP_CRLC_PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL(N) *(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL_TMP(n) - PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL(n-1))
PUT_DIF = PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL // change in resolution!!!
The boost pressure controller is inhibited by
- disabled PUT sensor
- torque limitation due to turbocharger protection LV_TCHA_PROT_ACT
- torque limitation due to intake system overpressure LV_IN_PROT or
- boost pressure actuator states different from ?AD? or ?OPM?
if LV_TCHA_PROT_ACT
or LV_IN_PROT
or!LV_ENA_PUT
or (LC_IDX_BPA_SWI = 1
and (
(STATE_BPA [0] != ?AD? and STATE_BPA [0] != ?OPM? )
#if NC_NR_BPA = 2
or (STATE_BPA [1] != ?AD? and STATE_BPA [1] != ?OPM? )
#endif
))
or PUT_SP < PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN + C_PUT_SP_DIF_INH_PUT_CTL
then LV_INH_PUT_CTL = 1
else LV_INH_PUT_CTL = 0
endif
The boost pressure controller I share is inhibited by
- too big boost pressure control deviation
- active minimum time control
- FARM
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(IN<NC_FID_INH_PUT_CTL_I>,OUT<PRM_LV_PRMS>)
if (not PRM_LV_PRMS)
or abs(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL) > C_PUT_DIF_MAX_STAT_DEAC
or FAC_2_POW_PUT_CTL_T_MIN > 0
then LV_INH_PUT_CTL_I = 1
else LV_INH_PUT_CTL_I = 0
endif
if FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL >= C_FAC_BPA_TOL_PUT_CTL_LIM
then LV_FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL_TOL = 1
else LV_FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL_TOL = 0
endif
if FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL <= C_FAC_BPA_BOL_PUT_CTL_LIM
or VP_BPA[0] < C_VP_BPA_MAX_PUT_CTL_BOL
#if NC_NR_BPA = 2
or VP_BPA[1] < C_VP_BPA_MAX_PUT_CTL_BOL
#endif
then LV_FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL_BOL = 1
else LV_FAC_BPA_PUT_CTL_BOL = 0
endif

10.21.2.2 Load step evaluation
// boost pressure setpoint low pass filter
if (PUT_SP < PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV) and (PUT_SP < PUT) then
if PUT < PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV then
PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV = PUT
else
PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV // remains unchanged
endif
else
PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV = min(PUT_SP, (PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV +
C_CRLC_PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV * (PUT_SP - PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV)))
endif
if ( max (PUT_SP,PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN) - PUT) < C_PUT_DIF_THD_PUT_SP_PREV then
PUT_SP_PREV = max (PUT_SP_LPF_PUT_PREV, PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN)
else
PUT_SP_PREV // remains unchanged
endif
// PUT_SP_PREV is boost pressure setpoint before current load step
// detection of boost pressure control undershoot
if PUT_SP > PUT_SP_PREV and PUT_SP > PUT then
// significantly rising boost pressure and
// positive boost pressure control deviation
switch STATE_PUT_CTL_SHO
case 0: // delay to ignore possible PUT jerk after throttle opening
CTR_DLY_PUT_CTL_SHO = max (0, CTR_DLY_PUT_CTL_SHO - 1)
if CTR_DLY_PUT_CTL_SHO == 0 then // waiting time elapsed
STATE_PUT_CTL_SHO = 1
endif
break
case 1: // search for great PUT gradient
if PUT_INC_MMV > C_PUT_INC_MMV_SHO_1 then
STATE_PUT_CTL_SHO = 2
endif
break
case 2: // search for PUT undershoot
if PUT_INC_MMV < C_PUT_INC_MMV_SHO_2 then
STATE_PUT_CTL_SHO = 3 // undershoot detected
endif
break
endswitch
else
STATE_PUT_CTL_SHO = 0 // small controller deviation
CTR_DLY_PUT_CTL_SHO = C_CTR_DLY_PUT_CTL_SHO
endif
if STATE_PUT_CTL_SHO == 3 then // undershoot detected
FAC_PUT_CTL_STAT = 0.9999847412109375
// maximum value, enforce stationary controller parameters
else
FAC_PUT_CTL_STAT = IP_FAC_PUT_CTL_STAT (PUT_SP - PUT_SP_PREV)
// fading between stationary and instationary controller parameters
endif
// weighting factor of stationary control parameters

10.21.2.3 Calculation of boost pressure controller P-D shares
// filter constant for low pass filtering near boost pressure setpoint
if abs(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL) < C_PUT_DIF_MAX_PUT_CTL_LPF
and abs(PUT_INC_MMV) < C_PUT_INC_MAX_PUT_CTL_LPF
then CRLC_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D = IP_CRLC_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D (N)
else CRLC_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D = 1
endif
// 3D map interpolation function calls
FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL_STEP = IP_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D
(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL, PUT_INC_MMV, N )
FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL_STAT = IP_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_STAT
(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL, PUT_INC_MMV, N )
// interpolation between maps for stationary/instationary operation
FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL_TMP_2 = C_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_STND *
(FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL_STEP + FAC_PUT_CTL_STAT *
(FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL_STAT - FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL_STEP))
FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL(n) = FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL(n-1) +
CRLC_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D *
(FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL_TMP_2 - FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_P_D_RGL(n-1))
10.21.2.4 Calculation of boost pressure controller I share
// 3D map interpolation function calls
FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_STEP = IP_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I
(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL, PUT_INC_MMV, N )
FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_STAT = IP_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_STAT
(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL, PUT_INC_MMV, N )
// interpolation between maps for stationary/instationary operation
FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_TMP_2 = C_FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_STND *
(FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_STEP + FAC_PUT_CTL_STAT *
(FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_STAT - FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_STEP))
// enforce I share step of at least 1 increment
If abs (FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_TMP_2) < 0.00305175 (1H)
Then FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL = sgn(FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_TMP)*0.00305175(1H)
Else FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL = FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_I_RGL_TMP_2
Endif

� General Information
As part of the turbocharger control IP_FAC_BPA_SP in module Turbocharger turbine control is the main source
for the boost pressure actuator setpoint to establish the required ?ow and pressure ratio at the turbocharger
turbine.
An adaptation is carried out to compensate series tolerances. The values of the adaptive mapIP_AD_FAC_BPA_SP
are saved in EEPROM during power latch phase and re-read at ECU reset.
They are used as a adaptive correction to the basic calibration IP_FAC_BPA_SP.
// de?ne software structure pointer for adaptive map
PRM_STRUCT_IP_AD_PTR(v) = pointer to <NC_STRUCT_IP_AD_FAC_BPA_SP[v]>
Index v works as Index for the VVL and corresponds to NC_NR_CASE_VVL (=1 in systems without VVL; =2 in
systems with VVL) As selection for VVL-operating-point L V_STATE_VVL_TCHA is used.

10.22.1 activation conditions for adaptation
if(1) N_PUT_AD_MAX - N_PUT_AD_MIN < C_N_WIN_PUT_AD
and MAF_STK_PUT_AD_MAX - MAF_STK_PUT_AD_MIN < C_MAF_STK_WIN_PUT_AD
and MAF_STK_SP_PUT_AD_MAX - MAF_STK_SP_PUT_AD_MIN < C_MAF_STK_SP_WIN_PUT_AD
// check for stationary engine operation
and PUT_SP >= PUT_POW_CHA_MIN
and PUT >= PUT_POW_CHA_MIN // check for boost operation
and abs(PUT_DIF_PUT_CTL) <= C_PUT_DIF_MAX_PUT_AD
// check for small boost pressure control deviation
and C_TIA_MIN_PUT_AD <= TIA_THR <= C_TIA_MAX_PUT_AD
and C_TCO_MIN_PUT_AD <= TCO <= C_TCO_MAX_PUT_AD
and LV_PUT_CTL_I_ACT = 1 // active boost pressure controller
and LV_PUT_CTL_I_LIM = 0 // boost pressure actuator at no limit
and LV_INH_PUT_AD = 0 // no other inhibition
Then(1) // ad-conditions fulfilled
A first adaptation step is done when the adaptation conditions have been fulfilled
for a time C_T_DLY_PUT_AD_INI, next steps with a (lower) delay time C_T_DLY_
PUT_AD_REP:
if (2) T_DLY_PUT_AD > 0 // delay time running
then(2) T_DLY_PUT_AD - 10 ms
else(2) T_DLY_PUT_AD = C_T_DLY_PUT_AD_REP
endif(2)
else(1) // ad-conditions NOT fulfilled
T_DLY_PUT_AD = C_T_DLY_PUT_AD_INI // re-init delay timer
// min/max reset
N_PUT_AD_MAX = N
N_PUT_AD_MIN = N
MAF_STK_PUT_AD_MAX = MAF_STK_TCHA
MAF_STK_PUT_AD_MIN = MAF_STK_TCHA
MAF_STK_SP_PUT_AD_MAX = MAF_STK_SP_TCHA
MAF_STK_SP_PUT_AD_MIN = MAF_STK_SP_TCHA
endif(1)
if (3) T_DLY_PUT_AD == 0 // delay time has elapsed
then (3) LV_PUT_AD_TRIG_tmp = 1 // TRIGGER for adaptation algorithm
else (3) LV_PUT_AD_TRIG_tmp = 0
endif (3)

General information:
In the exhaust manifold the exhaust gas ?ow through the outlet valves of the engine is divided into turbine
?ow, wastegate ?ow and the ?ow for external exhaust gas recirculation. The wastegate ?ow setpoint FLOW_

CHRG, Waste gate ?ow setpoint
WG_SP depends on the other three ?ows. In stationary operation (i.e. FLOW_ENG_TCHA has reached its set-
point FLOW_ENG_SP_TCHA after a FLOW_ENG_SP_TCHA jump) FLOW_WG_SP must be calculated based on
FLOW_WG_SP in order not to have a positive feedback which leads to growing engine ?ow and charged pres-
sure oscillations. Just after a FLOW_ENG_SP_TCHA jump FLOW_WG_SP must be calculated based on FLOW_
ENG_TCHA (<FLOW_ENG_SP_TCHA at this moment) because otherwise the wastegate opens too early. The
transition from FLOW_ENG_TCHA to FLOW_ENG_SP_TCHA as base for FLOW_WG_SP calculation is done when
either FLOW_ENG_MMV resp. FLOW_ENG_TCHA reaches its setpoint FLOW_ENG_SP_TCHA or when engine
?ow swings back before reaching its setpoint.
For a biturbo system all FLOW_xx represent the ?ows for one turbo charger.

FLOW_ENG_SP: Setpoint of gas mass ?ow through the exhaust valves of the engine
In the exhaust manifold the exhaust gas ?ow through the outlet valves of the engine is divided into turbine ?ow,
wastegate ?ow and the ?ow for external exhaust gas recirculation. The wastegate ?ow setpoint FLOW_WG_SP
depends on the other three ?ows. In stationary operation (i.e. FLOW_ENG_TCHA is near its setpoint FLOW_
ENG_SP_TCHA) FLOW_WG_SP must be calculated based on FLOW_ENG_SP in order not to have a positive
feedback which leads to growing engine ?ow and charged pressure oscillations.
For a biturbo system all FLOW_xx represent the ?ows for one turbo charger.

� General Information
This version is used for wastegate controled turbo chargers.
Based on FLOW_WG_SP for systems
- with position controlled turbine actuator a position setpoint POSN_SP_BPA is calculated
- without position controled turbine actuator a required pressure in the wastegate actuator PRS_WG_ACR_SP is
calculated.

CHRG, Turbocharger turbine control
For systems with electropneumatic wastegate actuator without position control a required pressure difference
in the wastegate actuator PRS_DIF_WG_ACR_SP_PCTL is calculated. The required difference pressure at the
wastegate actuator is stored in IP_FAC_BPA_SP in dependence of 2 input parameters. Wastegate pressure quo-
tient or pressure difference can be chosen as ?rst input. FLOW_WG_SP with or without temperature correction
can be chosen as second input.
The control signals for the inactive electrical boost pressure actuator are set as for minimum turbine power.

10.25.2.2 Calculation of special wastegate setpoint at low load
For compensation of noise due to a freely moving wastegate plate the wastegate position setpoint can be set
to 0 = closed position in case of idle speed/pull/pull fuel cutoff in combination with low vehicle speed or at
very low MAF_STK_TCHA. This anti noise function is deactivated with respect to hystereses. Time delays for
activation and deasctivation of the anti noise function can be applied.

Figure 10.25.3:
10.25.2.3 Coordination of wastegate setpoints
During the rising engine speed ramps (LV_N_SP_IS_TIPIN_SYN = 1) of the exhaust system short trip diagnosis
(LV_INH_ERR_EX_SYS = 0) the wastegate position setpoint POSN_SP_BPA_RGL_CUS can be forced close.
During active turbocharger minimum time control (FAC_2_POW_PUT_CTL_T_MIN>0) POSN_SP_BPA_RGL_CUS
is determined based on FAC_POW_PUT_CTL_T_MIN.
During normal operation the in?uence of customer speci?c wastegate setpoint POSN_SP_BPA_RGL_L_STAT is
weighted with intake manifold pressure control deviation from basic boost pressure PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN.

10.25.2.3.4 Selection of boost pressure setpoint strategy for low load
A separate boost pressure setpoint during catalyst heating can be activated via LC_POSN_SP_BPA_CH.
LC_POSN_SP_BPA_NOISE_PRI gives the anti-noise function priority over the regular boost pressure control. This
is forbidden
- if a separate boost pressure actuator for catalyst heating is active or
- in best response mode.

to engine speed N for better modeling of exhaust gas pressure oscillation in?uences.

10.26.2.4 Calculation of Turbine ?ow based on inverse turbine model
Turbine power factor FAC_POW_TUR_1 and standardized tubine speed N_TUR_COR represent a turbocharger
turbine operating point in the standard turbine maps.
Standardized turbine ?ow FLOW_TUR_1 is mapped in IP_FLOW_TUR_COR_PQ_TUR. IP_FLOW_TUR_COR_PQ_
TUR can be used
- without map decomposition (IP_PQ_TUR_REF == 0) or
- with map decomposition (IP_PQ_TUR_REF contains the pressure ratio of maximum turbine ef?ciency for each
turbine speed) for better numerical representation.
IP_PQ_TUR_DIF contains the turbine pressure ratio for given turbine power and speed. IP_PQ_TUR_DIF can be
used
- without map decomposition (IP_FAC_POW_TUR_REF == 0) or
- with map decomposition (IP_FAC_POW_TUR_REF contains the minimum relevant turbine power factor for
each turbine speed) for better numerical representation.
For low turbine pressure ratios (mainly throttled engine operation) turbine pressure ratio is modeled by IP_PQ_
TUR_L.

� General Information
The functional approach to this module has been made similar to the turbocharger protection module. For
an accurate understanding of this spec, it would be of help to go through the description of the turbocharger
protection.
General Information:
To protect the PUT-sensor against the high temperature TIA_THR, a torque reduction can be applied. Alterna-
tively by switching LC_TIA_TCHA_PROT temperature downsteam compressor TIA_CHA_DOWN can be chosen
as limited temperature. The outputs from this module shall be given as inputs to Turbocharger protection
module and the Torque setpoint would actually be set.
Function description
The physical limit is the maximum temperature of air at the throttle or downstream compressor respectively.
It is de?ned as the C_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX. A separate setpoint C_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX_SP is de?ned for con-
trolling the torque in such a way that C_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX would never be reached. TIA_THR is written on to
a variable TIA_THR_TCHA_PROT for the calculation in this module. The outputs from this module namely LV_
TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX_PROT, LV_TQI_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX and TQI_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX are de?ned as inputs
to the turbocharger protection module.
Based on the value TIA_THR_THCA_MAX_DIF_TRAN and its calculated gradient, the P controller gains are de-
?ned in the vector C_FAC_TQI_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX_P [4] and the I controller gains are de?ned in the vector
C_FAC_TQI_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX_I [4].
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, ES2ERU
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF&&LV_ST_END
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 100MS

� General Information
The turbocharger speed is limited because of component protection. The limit is de?ned by C_N_TCHA_MAX. If
turbocharger speed N_TCHA exceeds this "hard" limit for a de?ned time then the turbocharger is deactivated
by LV_N_TCHA_PROT = 1, which causes a torque limitation in the turbocharger protection module.
A second lower "soft" turbocharger speed limit is de?ned by IP_N_TCHA_MAX_SP, which is used as a setpoint
for turbocharger speed control via torque setpoint limitation TQI_N_TCHA_MAX.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, ES2ERU
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF==1
Deactivation: if activation not true

10.28.2.1 Deactivation of turbocharger because of too high turbocharger speed

� General Information
For big positive boost pressure setpoint jumps (recognized by high control signals coming from the regular
boost pressure precontrol + close loop control) a control sequence with a maximum boost pressure accelera-
tion (turbine control forced to maximum) and a constant boost pressure deceleration (turbine control forced
to constant near minimum) - bang-bang-control. The time when to switch from maximum acceleration to de-
celeration (= begin of minimum open loop control) and when to switch back to the steady control (= duration
of minimum open loop control) is adapted.

10.29.2.1 Subfunction: WRITE_ADAPTIVE_MAPS ()
// Prepare data for adaptation map writing in a local structure p
// Common parameters for both adaptation maps
p.PRM_WR_MOD = AREA_MOD (10h) // use "area mode" of map adaptation
// = modify both neighbor breakpoints
p.PRM_RATIO_SHIFT_PHY_RES = NCD_RATIO_SHIFT_FAC_T_BYTE_WORD
// with resolution ratio of adaptive map and target variable
// = 2?NCD_RATIO_SHIFT_FAC_T_BYTE_WORD = 2?8
p.PRM_LGRD_MAX = 1.9921875 // maximum allowed difference between
// neighbor points == no limitation
p.PRM_LIM_MIN = -1 // minimum allowed adaptation value
// == no limitation
p.PRM_LIM_MAX = 0.9921875 // maximum allowed adaptation value
// == no limitation
p.PRM_OPP_X = N_PUT_OPL_CTL_1 // set operating point of adaptive map
// to engine speed at begin of minimum open loop control
p.PRM_OPP_Y = GEAR

10.31.1 At reset
10.31.1.1 Initialization
Absolute and relative displayed boost pressure are initialized to neutral values. Maximum displayed boost
pressure BOP_MAX_DISP is set only here at initialization, an update of C_BOP_MAX_DISP is seen only after
reset. All other variables are initialized with zero.

10.31.2 OPM_100ms
10.31.2.1 Calculation of displayed boost pressure
The displayed boost pressure can be ?ltered as well on input side as BOP_DISP_BAS respectively BOP_SP_DISP_
BAS as on output side as BOP_ABS_DISP.
Dependent on project con?guration, which is taken place in the Boost pressure display (Appl. Inc), there is a
possibility to freeze the boost pressure for a certain time (LV_BOP__HLD = 1: e.g. during combustion state
transitions) and/or to switch to the according boost pressure set point (FAC_BOP_DISP > 0). To avoid sig-
nal discontinuity during state changes offsets are introduced if necessary (BOP_DISP_OFS).
LV_BOP_HLD, LV_BOP_SP_HLD, FAC_BOP_DISP, BOP_DISP_OFS, BOP_DISP_MAX and BOP_DISP_MIN are inputs
from Appl. Inc. module and have to be set according to project requirements.

10.31.2.1.2 Fading function, output side ?ltering and limitation of displayed boost pressure values
The fading block allows to mix current (measured) boost pressure value with boost pressure set point value,
controlled by FAC_BOP_DISP_FAD. The output of the fading block and the offset are summed up and low pass
?ltered. This ?lter output is limited to BOP_DISP_MAX resp. BOP_DISP_MIN and represents the displayed abso-
lute boost pressure value BOP_ABS_DISP. BOP_ABS_DISP is also used to calculate the relative boost pressure
value BOP_REL_DISP.

CHRG, Turbocharger diagnosis
� Import actions:
ACTION_ERRM_Record(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>, IN <PRM_STATE_FIL>)
ACTION_ERRM_Reset(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>)
ACTION_MISC_IpAdGetMinMax(IN <PRM_STRUCT_IP_AD_PTR>, OUT <PRM_LIM_MIN>, OUT <PRM_LIM_MAX>)
� General Information
This module performs three diagnosis operations from three different error sources. The ?rst diagnosis, which
tests if the turbo charger speed is too high, is called every 100 ms.
The second diagnosis tests if the adapted values of the basic charge air pressure (IP_AD_PUT_WG_OPEN) are
above or below de?ned thresholds.
Similar to the second diagnosis, the third diagnosis tests if the adapted values of the pressure control upstream
of throttle (PUT_CTL) are below or above de?ned thresholds.
The second and third diagnoses are called every second.
� Signal ?ow diagram:
10.32.1 Function description for 100ms
� General Information
For turbo charged engines charged engine operation is disabled for the rest of the current driving cycle if
charger speed exceeds a critical threshold. If this happens the error bit LV_ERR_TCHA_PROT is set. The symp-
tom of the error code is not handled by anti-bouncing.

CTL adaptation every second.

CHRG, Turbocharger diagnosis
Basic charge air pressure adaptation diagnosis (IP_AD_PUT_WG_OPEN)
Tests if the adapted values of the basic charge air pressure (IP_AD_PUT_WG_OPEN) are above or below de?ned
thresholds (C_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD_BOL and C_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD_TOL, respectively). If at least one value in
IP_AD_PUT_WG_OPEN is outside of the thresholds, the error ?ag LV_ERR_PUT_WG_OPEN_AD is set. No anti-
bounce ?lters are used.
Error Treatment
Figure 10.32.6:
PUT_CTL diagnosis
Tests if the adapted values of the pressure control upstream of throttle (PUT_CTL) are below or above de?ned
thresholds (C_FAC_PUT_AD_BOL_DIAG and C_FAC_PUT_AD_TOL_DIAG, respectively). If at least one value in
FAC_PUT_AD is outside of the thresholds, the error ?ag LV_ERR_FAC_PUT_AD is set. No anti-bounce ?lters are
used.
Error Treatment

� General Information
The purpose of this diagnosis is to detect several failures related with the charge air pressure and the wastegate
behaviour.
In case the charge air pressure is too high any of the following reasons could cause this bad behaviour:
wastegate stuck closed
defect engine
closed exhaust system
defect EPC pressure supply or stuck closed
If this failure is present, the turbo charge protection will react to avoid to damage the engine and to ensure a
good driveability of the car.(see Turbo Protection Speci?cation)
In case the charge air pressure is too low any of the following reasons could cause this bad behaviour:
defect charger
leaky air tube or intercooler
recirculation valve stuck open
defect EPC stuck open
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, EXITST, IGKON
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF && LV_ST_END
Deactivation: !LC_TCHA_CONF || !LV_ST_END
Recurrence: 10MS

Figure 10.33.1:
10.33.1 Initialization at ignition
-The initialization of the delay times is done after reset or exit start.
-The initialization of the diagnosis (LF_STATE_DGO_xxxx,LV_CND_DIAG_xx) is done after reset , ignition-key-on
or LV_DIAG_RST_xxx (triggered every second)
The LV_DIAG_RST_xxx are calculated in the ERRM interface module.
-LV_DIAG_RST_CAP_H depending on ACTION_CHRG_ResetDiagCapH
-LV_DIAG_RST_CAP_L depending on ACTION_CHRG_ResetDiagCapL
-LV_DIAG_RST_CAP_L_BAS depending onACTION_CHRG_ResetDiagCapLBas

10.35.2 Delay time for Rate based monitoring
� General Information
Rate based monitoring for turbocharger diagnoses is requested only after the engine was in boost operation
twice for a short period (typically 2 s) or overall for a longer time (typically 10 s).
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at ECU reset
LV_T_DLY_TCHA_RBM = 0
T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_1 = C_T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_1
T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_2 = C_T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_2
LV_CDN_TCHA_RBM = 0
ACTION_FARM_SetAuxiliaryStatus (NC_IDX_FID_CDN_TCHA_RBM, 0)
// Turbocharger specific RBM conditions not fulfilled
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF == 1
Deactivation: if activation condition not true
Recurrence: 100 ms
� Function Description
if PUT_SP - PUT_POW_TCHA_MIN > C_PUT_DIF_MIN_TCHA_RBM and LV_ST_END == 1 then
// boost operation requested
T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_1 = T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_1 - 0.1 s
T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_2 = T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_2 - 0.1 s
else
// no boost operation
if T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_2 > 0 then // short period not finished yet

LV_T_DLY_TCHA_RBM = 1
endif
endif
endif

(T_DLY_TCHA_RBM_2 <= 0 and LV_T_DLY_TCHA_RBM == 1)) then

10.35.3 Rate based monitoring interface for Turbocharger overpressure diagnosis
� General Information
Interface between monitors and rate-based monitoring functionality is mainly realized with 3 actions:
- ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorNumFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
- ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorDenFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
- ACTION_ERRM_LockRbmMonitorFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
STATE_RBM_PRS_DIF_UP_THR variable is only used to facilitate computations and prepare Actions calls.
These 3 actions shall be called to increment individual numerator/denominator of related monitor.
Within STATE_RBM_PRS_DIF_UP_THR, three different information are de?ned:
? Conditions for monitoring are met long enough to detect malfunction (bit 0)
(no intrusive operation, no short trip)
? Monitor disabled because of system malfunction (bit 1)
(depending on failure status: pending)
? Monitor individual RBM conditions encountered within this driving cycle (bit 2) (not valid for this diagno-
sis)
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at ECU reset
bit 0, bit 1 and bit 2 of STATE_RBM_PRS_DIF_UP_THR = 0
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF == 1
Deactivation: activation condition not true
Recurrence: 1 s
� Function Description
If bit 1 of STATE_RBM_PRS_DIF_UP_THR == 0 Then
Monitor disablement because of system malfunction
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(NC_FID_ERR_PRS_DIF_UP_THR, PRM_LV_PRMS)

bit 1 of STATE_RBM_PRS_DIF_UP_THR = 1
ACTION_ERRM_LockRbmMonitorFor(IN<NC_IDX_RBM_PRS_DIF_UP_THR>)
Endif
Endif

CHRG, Turbocharger plausibility diagnosis
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
LC_N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_RCL - 0... 1H 0 ...1 1 -
Activation of active recirculation actuator test in case of suspicion of a leakage upstream throttle
� General Information
This function is used to detect if a possible leakage before the throttle has occured, based on the value of the
PSN_TUR_SP_CLL and the corresponding adapted value FAC_PUT_AD_ADD, at stationary conditions.
LV_INH_ERR_LEAK_UP_THR inhibits the leakage diagnosis, when an actuator problem is already discovered.
When the stationary conditions are detected based on the PUT and PUT_SP , a counter C_T_DLY_N_TCHA_
MAX_SP_PROT_DIF is set to countdown and if the counter T_DLY_N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF reaches zero,
and there is no error of the actuator in charged operation, the PSN_TUR_SP_DIAG is compared to the threshold
value. If the value PSN_TUR_SP_DIAG is over the threshold then there is a reduction in the maximum tur-
bocharger speed based on engine speed, and the value by which the maximum turbocharger speed should
be reduced N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF is given as output.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF && LV_ST_END
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 10MS

10.37.2.2.3.2.2.1 Calculation of the turbocharger speed reduction
This calculation is done only when it is identi?ed that the closed loop controller value and the adapted value
are above a de?ned threshold.
Via LC_N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_FIRST can be chosen, whether turbocharger speed reduction will be done
as soon as N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_TMP >C_N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_THD (already before debounc-
ing =1) or only after (=0) debouncing.
N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF is ramped in with increment C_N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_INC.

Figure 10.37.16:
10.37.2.2.5 Leakage diagnosis when the recirculation valve is part of the turbocharger system
For further reference hereon, the opening of the recirculation valve until the beginning of the following opening
is considered as one cycle.
When it is detected that there is a reduction in the setpoint of the maximum turbocharger speed caused due
to high controller values than expected, a bit LV_N_TCHA_MAX_SP_PROT_DIF_ACT is set. This bit is used to then
initiate an opening and closing of the recirculation valve at regular intervals in the trailing throttle operation.
Once the opening of the recirculation valve is initiated in the trailing throttle phase a bit LV_RCL_DIAG_OPEN_
ACT is set. Everytime this bit is set as a step from zero to 1, the PUT value is memorised as PUT_MEM_LEAK_
DIAG_1, the difference between the memorised PUT_MEM_LEAK_DIAG_1 and the PUT for the entire open and
close period of the recirculation valve is calculated as an integral PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG_1. It is shown as Area
1.
The integral PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG_1 also includes the area when the recirculation valve is closed too, and there-
fore the triangle Area 2 as shown in ?gure below should be subtracted from the Area1. The correspond-
ing value (Area1 minus Area 2) is stored as PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG_TMP. At the end of every cycle, the value
of PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG_TMP is cumulatively added to the PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG. The PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG is
then compared at the end of the completion of the C_CTR_RCL_OPEN_DIAG_MAX cycles to the PUT_INT_
LEAK_DIAG_THD value. If the PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG is greater than the PUT_INT_LEAK_DIAG_THD, it means
that the recirculation valve is not stuck open. The anamoly of the controller value can then be diagnosed for
the leakage before the throttle.

� Import actions:
ACTION_ERRM_Record(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>, IN <PRM_STATE_FIL>)
ACTION_ERRM_Reset(IN <PRM_IDX_ERR>)
� Error treatment
Diagnostic Identi?er Diagnostic description NR_CONF CARB OBD DTC
Diagnostic initialisation function Status diagnostic result
NC_IDX_ERR_LEAK_UP_THR Index for a possible leakage upstream throttle diagnosis 0 CC
ACTION_CHRG_ResetDiagLeakUpThr "UNUSED"
� General Information
This module de?nes the interface functionality between main module for Turbocharger plausibility diagnosis
and error management (ERRM). This variant covers ERRM 6.x.
The main interface variable is LF_STATE_DGO_LEAK_UP_THR.
These bit coded variables have following meaning:
Bit 0: Condition ful?lled if set to 1
Bit 1: Failure symptom present if set to 1
A REST or CLR of the main diagnosis is ensured via checking the values of
LV_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR_CLR and LV_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR_REST. These quantities are set inside the action AC-
TION_CHRG_ResetDiagLeakUpThr and reset inside function "Handling of CLR and REST request".
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At RST and IGKON events:
ACTION_ERRM_Reset(IN <NC_IDX_ERR_LEAK_UP_THR>)
ACTION_CHRG_ResetDiagLeakUpThr(?CLR?)
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF = 1 && LV_ST_END = 1
Deactivation: if activation not true
Recurrence: 10ms
� Function Description
LV_CDN_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR = bit 0 of LF_STATE_DGO_LEAK_UP_THR
LV_SYM_LEAK_UP_THR = bit 1 of LF_STATE_DGO_LEAK_UP_THR
If LV_CDN_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR = 1
Then
state_fil_leak_up_thr_prev = STATE_FIL_LEAK_UP_THR
STATE_FIL_LEAK_UP_THR = ?NO_EVE?
Symptom filtering :
If LV_SYM_LEAK_UP_THR = 1

Then
STATE_FIL_LEAK_UP_THR = ?FAIL?
Else
STATE_FIL_LEAK_UP_THR = ?PASS?

Error Management storage :
If state_fil_leak_up_thr_prev <> STATE_FIL_LEAK_UP_THR
Then
ACTION_ERRM_Record (IN<NC_IDX_ERR_LEAK_UP_THR>, IN<STATE_FIL_LEAK_UP_THR>)
Endif
Endif
Handling of CLR and REST request
LV_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR_CLR = 0
LV_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR_REST = 0
ACTION_CHRG_ResetDiagLeakUpThr
STATE_FIL_LEAK_UP_THR = NO_EVE
LV_CDN_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR = 0
LV_SYM_LEAK_UP_THR = 0
If PRM_STATE_INI = ?CLR?
Then
LV_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR_CLR = 1
Else
LV_DIAG_LEAK_UP_THR_REST = 1

the monitor because of system failure(s) Bit 2: individual RBM conditions of the monitor were encountered within this DC

10.40.2 Interface for RBM ? Charge air pressure LOW diagnosis (CAP_L)
� General Information
Interface between monitors and rate-based monitoring functionality is mainly realized with 3 actions:
- ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorNumFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
- ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorDenFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
- ACTION_ERRM_LockRbmMonitorFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
STATE_RBM_CAP_L variable is only used to facilitate computations and prepare Actions calls.
These 3 actions shall be called to increment individual numerator/denominator of related monitor.
Within STATE_RBM_CAP_L, three different information are de?ned:
? Conditions for monitoring are met long enough to detect malfunction (bit 0)
(no intrusive operation, no short trip)
? Monitor disabled because of system malfunction (bit 1)

? Monitor individual RBM conditions encountered within this driving cycle (bit 2) (not valid for CAP_L diag-

� General Information
The purpose of this module is to diagnose the recirculation actuator for stuck close or stuck open.
Stuck close diagnosis:
As long as the recirculation valve actuator is deactivated, the recirculation valve RCL valve is closed (the spring
force pushes the membrane). The activation of the RCL valve actuator must lead to a smooth decrease of the
pressure upstream throttle PUT. If it is not veri?ed (strong PUT oscillations noticed), we conclude that the valve
remains stuck in closed position).
Stuck open diagnosis:
In part load, the RCL valve is not activated (except in case of necessity of manifold protection from over-
pressure) and the pressure upstream throttle reaches high values in charger mode. If the pressure upstream
throttle is not suf?cient then we conclude that the RCL valve is stuck in fully open position.
This diagnosis can detect an RCL valve stuck in fully open position or any equivalent [if C_PUT_MDL_RCL_
OPEN_DIF_NEG calibrated with a small value, e.g.: 30hPa] or higher [if C_PUT_MDL_RCL_OPEN_DIF_NEG cal-
ibrated with a high value, e.g.: 200hPa] air leakage between the output of the compressor and upstream
the throttle. This leakage could be the consequence of a hose disconnected on the Intake system, a porous
intercooler or a wastegate stuck in intermediate or in fully open position.
The result of the diagnosis must be "RCL open or Porous Intercooler or Hose disconnected or Air leakage
between the output of the compressor and upstream the throttle" (1 unique Pcode).
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, IGKON
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF
Deactivation: !LC_TCHA_CONF
Recurrence: 10MS

10.41.2.1.2.2 STUCK_CLOSE_DIAG: Temporary value for T_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL
The initialization of counter (T_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL=10) is trigged by the switching of RCL valve from ?close? to
?open? position ,and also when the condition depending on the pressure ratio at charger ,gear shift detection
and the vehicle speed are ful?lled.
The main condition to start counting is that the initialization was done ( T_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL=10), otherwise
the counter should be reset.

10.41.2.1.3 Diagnostic of RCL stuck close
The diagnostic is done in 2 steps:
Evaluation of diagnostic condition
Symptom detection
If LF_STATE_DGO_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL = 0 (NO-CDN NO-SYM), the RCL valve closes correctly; PUT_RCL_INT is
always <PUT_RCL_INT_THD_OPEN in this case because of LV_CDN_DIAG_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL de?nition.
In case of PUT_RCL_INT_THD_OPEN < PUT_RCL_INT < PUT_RCL_INT_THD_CLOSE the position of the valve
cannot be distinguished between closed and open and LV_CDN_DIAG_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL = 0.

10.43.2 RBM interface for RCL Plausibilty - stucked close - diagnosis
� General Information
Interface between monitors and rate-based monitoring functionality is mainly realized with 3 actions:
- ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorNumFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
- ACTION_ERRM_IncRbmMonitorDenFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
- ACTION_ERRM_LockRbmMonitorFor (IN<PRM_IDX_RBM>)
STATE_RBM_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL variable is only used to facilitate computations and prepare Actions calls.
These 3 actions shall be called to increment individual numerator/denominator of related monitor.
Within STATE_RBM_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL, three different information are de?ned:
- Conditions for monitoring are met long enough to detect malfunction (bit 0)
(no intrusive operation, no short trip)
- Monitor disabled because of system malfunction (bit 1)
(depending on failure status: pending)
- Monitor individual RBM conditions encountered within this driving cycle (bit 2) (not valid
for PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL diagnosis)
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at RST system event
bit 0, bit 1 and bit 2 of STATE_RBM_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL = 0
Activation: LC_TCHA_CONF =1 And LV_FID_READY=1
Deactivation: activation condition not true
Recurrence: 1 s
� Function Description
If bit 1 of STATE_RBM_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL = 0 Then
ACTION_FARM_GetPermission ( IN<NC_FID_RBM_PLAUS_CLOSE_RCL >,
OUT <PRM_LV_PRMS> )

Monitor disablement because of system malfunction

OUT<PRM_LV_END_DIAG>)

� General Information
The purpose of this diagnosis is to detect end of line failures for leakage upstream throttle ,intake manifold air
pressure (MAP),pressure upstream throttle (PUT) and boost failure.
For the MAP and PUT diagnosis the failure is detected for high or low values.
The boost failure could provide from the waste-gate ,the RCL or from leakage in the exhaust path.
10.44.1 Calculation of LF_STATE_DGO_XX (Core)
� General Information
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_BOOST =0
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_LEAK_UP_THR =0
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_MAP =0
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_PUT =0
Activation: Always
Deactivation: Never
Recurrence: 10ms
� Function Description
//End of line diagnosis for Boost
if(1) LV_DIAG_EOL_BOOST == 1
then
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_BOOST =1 //CDN-NOSYM
elseif(1) LV_DIAG_EOL_BOOST_ERR == 1
then
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_BOOST =3 //CDN-SYM
else(1)
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_BOOST =0 //NOCDN-SYM
end(1)

else(2)

//End of line diagnosis for MAP
if(3) LV_MAP_DIAG_EOL == 1
then
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_MAP =1 //CDN-NOSYM
elseif(3) LV_MAP_L_DIAG_EOL == 1 OR LV_MAP_H_DIAG_EOL == 1
then
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_MAP =3 //CDN-SYM
else(3)
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_MAP =0 //NOCDN-NOSYM
end(3)
//End of line diagnosis for PUT
if(4) LV_PUT_DIAG_EOL == 1
then
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_PUT =1 //CDN-NOSYM
elseif(4) LV_PUT_L_DIAG_EOL == 1 OR LV_PUT_H_DIAG_EOL == 1
then
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_PUT =3 //CDN-SYM
else(4)
LF_STATE_DGO_EOL_PUT =0 //NOCDN-NOSYM
end(4)

This image is a Simulink diagram representing a control or monitoring logic for charge air temperature.

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and derive various charge air temperature-related values, including downward adjustment references, plausibility-checked nominal temperatures, and upward adjustment limits. It processes raw temperature inputs, applies physical limits, rate limiting (or similar checks), and constant offsets to generate control or diagnostic signals related to charge air temperature in an automotive system. The overall goal appears to be ensuring charge air temperature values remain within safe and operational bounds and to provide relevant signals for further control strategies.

## Inputs

1.  **TIA_THRS**: A threshold value for charge air temperature, used as a reference for downward adjustments.
2.  **STATE_TAM_N_TCHA**: The current state or measured nominal charge air temperature.
3.  **<TAM>**: An input representing ambient temperature or another relevant temperature, used in upward adjustment calculations.
4.  **phys_min**: A constant/parameter defining the physical minimum limit for `STATE_TAM_N_TCHA`.
5.  **phys_max**: A constant/parameter defining the physical maximum limit for `STATE_TAM_N_TCHA`.
6.  **T_TAM_N_TCHA**: A parameter/constant within block V.6.7, likely representing a nominal temperature or a specific limit for comparison.
7.  **Constants**:
    *   `0` (used for `<FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE>`)
    *   `1` (used for `<FAC_TIA_COR_TEMP>`, `<RATIO_TIA_CMPR>`, `<RATIO_TIA_CMPR_SP>`)
    *   `2` (labeled `recentlyupdated` within block V.6.2, likely a status or counter)
    *   `50` (an offset added to processed `<TAM>`)
    *   `273` (an offset added to processed `STATE_TAM_N_TCHA`, possibly for Kelvin conversion if other values are in Celsius).

## Outputs

1.  **TIA_CHA_DOWN_MV**: Measured value for charge air temperature downward adjustment.
2.  **TIA_CHA_DOWN_SP**: Setpoint for charge air temperature downward adjustment.
3.  **<FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE>**: A factor or flag related to saving nominal charge air temperature.
4.  **<FAC_TIA_COR_TEMP>**: A factor for charge air temperature correction.
5.  **<RATIO_TIA_CMPR>**: A ratio related to charge air compression.
6.  **<RATIO_TIA_CMPR_SP>**: A setpoint ratio related to charge air compression.
7.  **<T_TAM_N_TCHA>**: The plausibility-checked and limited nominal charge air temperature.
8.  **TIA_ABSv_CHA_UP**: An absolute upward charge air temperature value.
9.  **TIA_CHA_UP**: The final upward charge air temperature limit or value.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow can be broken down into four main paths:

**1. Downward Charge Air Temperature Signals:**
*   The input `TIA_THRS` directly generates two output signals: `TIA_CHA_DOWN_MV` and `TIA_CHA_DOWN_SP`. This suggests `TIA_THRS` serves as a direct reference or is duplicated for both measured value and setpoint in this context.

**2. Plausibility Checking and Limiting for Nominal Charge Air Temperature:**
*   The `STATE_TAM_N_TCHA` input first passes through block V.6.2 (a block potentially performing a conditional check or processing based on the `recentlyupdated` status).
*   The output of V.6.2 is then fed into a Saturation/Limiter block (V.6.7). This block limits the incoming temperature value using `phys_min` and `phys_max` as its lower and upper bounds, respectively. `T_TAM_N_TCHA` is also a parameter for this block, potentially influencing the limiting behavior or serving as a nominal reference within the block.
*   The output of this limiter block is the final `<T_TAM_N_TCHA>`, representing the physically plausible nominal charge air temperature.

**3. Upward Charge Air Temperature Adjustment Calculation:**
*   **Path A (from STATE_TAM_N_TCHA):** The `STATE_TAM_N_TCHA` input also feeds into a conditional Rate Limiter or Saturation block (V.6.6) characterized by `Check == 0`.

*   The output of this limiter block is the final `<T_TAM_N_TCHA>`, representing the physically plausible nominal charge air temperature.

**3. Upward Charge Air Temperature Adjustment Calculation:**
*   **Path A (from STATE_TAM_N_TCHA):** The `STATE_TAM_N_TCHA` input also feeds into a conditional Rate Limiter or Saturation block (V.6.6) characterized by `Check == 0`. The processed output from V.6.6 is then added to a constant `273` (likely for a temperature scale conversion, e.g., Celsius to Kelvin) in a Sum block (V.6.1). The result of this sum is the `TIA_ABSv_CHA_UP` output signal.
*   **Path B (from <TAM>):** The `<TAM>` input feeds into a similar conditional Rate Limiter or Saturation block (V.6.6) with `Check == 0`. The processed output from this V.6.6 block is then added to a constant `50` in a Sum block (V.6.4).
*   **Final Upward Calculation:** The output from Path A (`TIA_ABSv_CHA_UP`) and the output from Path B (processed `<TAM>` + 50) are both fed into a final block (V.6.1). This block likely combines these two values to determine the ultimate `TIA_CHA_UP` output. Given the "CHA_UP" context, this could be a 'Maximum' operation, taking the highest of the two input values as the upward limit.

**4. Constant Value Assignments:**
*   Several output signals are directly assigned constant values:
    *   `<FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE>` is set to `0`.
    *   `<FAC_TIA_COR_TEMP>` is set to `1`.
    *   `<RATIO_TIA_CMPR>` is set to `1`.
    *   `<RATIO_TIA_CMPR_SP>` is set to `1`.
    These outputs might represent flags, default scaling factors, or placeholders for future dynamic calculations.

This image is a Simulink diagram.

## Function
The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate the "Air Temperature Upstream Turbocharger Compressor" (`TIA_CHA_UP`). This calculation is dynamic, adapting between different input temperature sources (`TIA_THR` or `TAM`) based on their availability, reliability, and specific operating conditions, while also incorporating various corrections, absolute limits, and fallback mechanisms, including a substitute value and fading logic for sensor unreliability.

## Inputs
1.  `C_STATE_TIA_CMPR_CLC`: A control state indicating the preferred calculation mode for the compressor temperature (e.g., whether to prioritize `TIA_THR` or `TAM`).
2.  `LC_TAM_N_TCHA_TIA_THR`: A logic signal, likely indicating the availability or reliability of `TIA_THR` in relation to `TAM` and `N_TCHA`.
3.  `MAF_KGH_THR_TCHA`: Mass Air Flow (kg/h) related to the turbocharger hot-side. Used as an input to lookup tables.
4.  `TIA_THR`: Air Temperature (e.g., Celsius) at the turbocharger hot-side.
5.  `TAM`: Ambient Temperature (e.g., Celsius).
6.  `STATE_TAM_N_TCHA`: State variable indicating the update status or reliability of `TAM` for `N_TCHA` (turbocharger speed).
7.  `TIA_CHA_DOWN_MV`: A feedback signal, potentially representing a minimum or lower dynamic limit for the compressor upstream air temperature.
8.  `IP_CRLC_TIA_CMPR_UP_POS`: Data for a 2D lookup table, defining positive correction values for the compressor upstream temperature.
9.  `IP_CRLC_TIA_CMPR_UP_NEG`: Data for a 2D lookup table, defining negative correction values for the compressor upstream temperature.
10. `IP_TIA_AIC_DOWN_OFS`: A parameter representing an offset for intake air charge correction, typically for de-warming.
11. `C_T_TAM_N_TCHA`: A constant (mentioned in text, not explicitly a block input) representing a time threshold for `T_TAM_N_TCHA` to trigger `FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE` state.

## Outputs
1.  `TIA_CHA_UP`: The primary calculated output: Air Temperature Upstream Turbocharger Compressor.
2.

11. `C_T_TAM_N_TCHA`: A constant (mentioned in text, not explicitly a block input) representing a time threshold for `T_TAM_N_TCHA` to trigger `FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE` state.

## Outputs
1.  `TIA_CHA_UP`: The primary calculated output: Air Temperature Upstream Turbocharger Compressor.
2.  `TIA_ABSV_CHA_UP`: An intermediate output representing the regulated absolute air temperature upstream of the compressor.
3.  `FAC_TAM_N_TCHA_SAVE`: A flag (boolean or integer) indicating the status of `TAM` reliability or update, specifically for saving a value (e.g., `1` for unreliable/not updated, `0` for reliable/updated).
4.  `T_TAM_N_TCHA`: The time elapsed since the last update of `TAM` (or related state), used for fading logic.
5.  `TIA_CMPR_UP_OFS_RGL`: An offset or regulation value for the compressor upstream temperature.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow calculates `TIA_CHA_UP` through a multi-branch approach based on sensor states and environmental conditions:

1.  **Selection of Base Temperature Calculation Path (TIA_THR vs. TAM):**
    *   An `If-Else` block (V.6.0) determines the primary calculation path based on two conditions:
        *   `C_STATE_TIA_CMPR_CLC` is compared to `2` (`C_STATE_TIA_CMPR_CLC >= 2`).
        *   `LC_TAM_N_TCHA_TIA_THR` is compared to `0`.
        *   An `AND` gate combines these: `(C_STATE_TIA_CMPR_CLC >= 2) AND (LC_TAM_N_TCHA_TIA_THR == 0)`.
    *   **If TRUE (TIA_THR-based Path):** This path (labeled "Calculate TIA_CHA_UP based on TIA_THR?") uses `MAF_KGH_THR_TCHA` and `TIA_THR` as inputs to 2D lookup tables (`IP_CRLC_TIA_CMPR_UP_POS`, `IP_CRLC_TIA_CMPR_UP_NEG`). These tables output `x_val` which is then processed through comparators (V.6.2, V.6.6) against `TIA_THR` and `0` to determine an intermediate `IP_val` and ultimately a temporary absolute temperature (`tia_absv_cha_up_tmp`). This path likely calculates an upper/lower bound or correction for the temperature based on turbocharger operating conditions.

## Function
The Simulink diagram primarily functions to estimate and regulate the "Charge air temperature" (CHRG) for an automotive system, likely within an engine control unit. It achieves this by:

2.  **Calculating a Compressor Upstream Offset:** It determines a regulated offset (`TIA_CMPR_UP_OFS_RGL`) for the compressor upstream based on mass air flow, ambient temperature, and a 2D lookup table.
3.  **Fading and Absolute Temperature Conversion:** It combines a saved charge air temperature constant with a dynamic factor using a fading function to produce an intermediate temperature, which is then converted to an absolute temperature (`tia_absv_cha_up_tmp`).

The system aims to provide critical temperature values and offsets for precise control of air charging, influencing engine performance and emissions. The accompanying text suggests these calculations are part of determining the air temperature downstream of the charger (`TIA_CHA_DOWN`).

## Function
The primary function of this system is to detect a compressor surge condition. It achieves this by first dynamically determining surge line thresholds based on measured and predicted charge air volume flow. These thresholds are then compared against current and predicted charge air pressure/flow values. The system uses a latched flag for the main surge detection and a separate "capture surge" flag that considers throttle position, likely for diagnostic or specific control purposes.

## Inputs
1.  **`VOL_FLOW_CHA_UP_RED_MV`**: Measured reduced upstream charge air volume flow. (Analog/Float)
2.  **`VOL_FLOW_CHA_UP_RED_PRED`**: Predicted reduced upstream charge air volume flow. (Analog/Float)
3.  **`PQ_CHA_MV`**: Measured charge air pressure/flow value. (Analog/Float)
4.  **`PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL`**: Dynamically calculated surge line threshold for measured charge air values. (Intermediate from sub-system 10.10.1.2)
5.  **`PQ_CHA_PRED`**: Predicted charge air pressure/flow value. (Analog/Float)
6.  **`PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL_PRED`**: Dynamically calculated surge line threshold for predicted charge air values. (Intermediate from sub-system 10.10.1.2)
7.  **`PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL_HYS`**: Hysteresis surge line threshold, typically lower than the surge detection threshold, used for resetting the surge flag. (Analog/Float)
8.  **`TPS_SP_MDL_MAX`**: Maximum throttle position sensor model value. (Analog/Float)
9.  **`TPS_SP_MDL`**: Current throttle position sensor model value. (Analog/Float)
10. **`C_TPS_AV_RCL_DIF_MIN`**: A constant representing the minimum difference for throttle position average recirculation. (Constant/Parameter)

## Outputs
1.  **`LV_CMPR_SURGE`**: A latched boolean flag indicating that a compressor surge condition has been detected. Once set, it remains true until reset conditions are met. (Boolean)
2.  **`LV_CAP_SURGE`**: A boolean flag indicating a "capture surge" condition, which is momentary and dependent on both surge conditions and throttle position. (Boolean)

## Logic Flow

The system operates in two main stages: "Read out surge line" and "Surge detection".

### Stage 1: Read out surge line (Figure 10.10.2)
1.  **Surge Line Calculation for Measured Flow**:
    *   The input `VOL_FLOW_CHA_UP_RED_MV` (measured reduced upstream charge air volume flow) is fed as the 'x_val' to a 1D lookup table named `IP_PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL` (V.7.11).
    *   This lookup table, which likely defines the surge line characteristic, outputs a value `IP_val`.
    *   This `IP_val` is then output as `PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL`, representing the surge line threshold for measured charge air values.
2.  **Surge Line Calculation for Predicted Flow**:
    *   Similarly, the input `VOL_FLOW_CHA_UP_RED_PRED` (predicted reduced upstream charge air volume flow) is fed as the 'x_val' to an identical 1D lookup table `IP_PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL` (V.7.11).
    *   This lookup table outputs an `IP_val`.
    *   This `IP_val` is then output as `PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL_PRED`, representing the surge line threshold for predicted charge air values.

### Stage 2: Surge detection (Figure 10.10.3)
This stage uses the calculated surge lines along with other inputs to determine surge conditions.

1.  **Compressor Surge (Set Logic for Flip-Flop)**:
    *   Two comparison blocks (V.6.6) check for surge conditions:
        *   `PQ_CHA_MV` (measured charge value) > `PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL` (calculated surge line for measured values).
        *   `PQ_CHA_PRED` (predicted charge value) > `PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL_PRED` (calculated surge line for predicted values).
    *   The boolean outputs of these two comparisons are fed into an `OR` gate (V.6.7).

*   `PQ_CHA_PRED` (predicted charge value) > `PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL_PRED` (calculated surge line for predicted values).
    *   The boolean outputs of these two comparisons are fed into an `OR` gate (V.6.7).
    *   If either of these conditions is true, the `OR` gate outputs true, which acts as the `SET` signal for an SR Flip-Flop (FF, V.6.12).

2.  **Compressor Surge (Reset Logic for Flip-Flop)**:
    *   A comparison block (V.6.6) checks for a reset condition:
        *   `PQ_CHA_MV` (measured charge value) < `PQ_CHA_SURGE_DL_HYS` (hysteresis surge line threshold).
    *   If this condition is true, it acts as the `RST` signal for the SR Flip-Flop (FF, V.6.12). This allows the surge flag to be cleared only when the measured value significantly drops below the surge line, preventing oscillations.

3.  **Latched Compressor Surge Output (`LV_CMPR_SURGE`)**:
    *   The `Q` output of the SR Flip-Flop (FF, V.6.12) directly drives the `LV_CMPR_SURGE` signal (V.6.8). This means `LV_CMPR_SURGE` will go true (high) if a surge condition (set logic) occurs and will remain true until the reset condition is met.

4.  **Capture Surge Output (`LV_CAP_SURGE`)**:
    *   **Throttle Position Condition**:
        *   `TPS_SP_MDL_MAX` and `C_TPS_AV_RCL_DIF_MIN` are summed.
        *   This sum is compared with `TPS_SP_MDL` (current throttle model value) in a comparison block (V.6.6): `TPS_SP_MDL` > (`TPS_SP_MDL_MAX` + `C_TPS_AV_RCL_DIF_MIN`). This checks if the throttle is in a specific operating range.
    *   **Combined Surge and Throttle Condition**:
        *   The boolean output of the `OR` gate from the Set logic (i.e., the primary surge detection) and the boolean output of the throttle position condition are fed into an `AND` gate (V.6.10).
    *   The output of this `AND` gate is `LV_CAP_SURGE`. This signal is only true if a surge condition is detected (measured or predicted) AND the throttle is in the specified high operating range.

## Function
The primary function of this system is to calculate and transform parameters related to engine volumetric efficiency, turbocharger operating limits, and boost pressure control. It encompasses:
1.  **Calculation of Compressor Volumetric Efficiency Parameters:** Deriving compressor-specific slope and offset values from general volumetric efficiency.
2.  **Turbocharger Operating Limits:** Determining maximum turbocharger speed, pressure, and mass air flow limits for both performance and protection.
3.  **Coordinate Transformation:** Transforming volumetric efficiency parameters into coordinates suitable for turbocharger compressor maps.
These calculations are essential for precisely controlling boost pressure, optimizing engine performance, and ensuring the longevity and safe operation of the turbocharger.

## Inputs
The system takes the following inputs (green blocks):
*   `EFF_VOL_OFS_SUM`: Sum of volumetric efficiency offsets.
*   `EFF_VOL_SLOP`: Volumetric efficiency slope.
*   `PRS_AIC_DOWN_MAX`: Maximum allowable intake pressure after intercooler.
*   `TIA_ABSV_CHA_UP`: Absolute temperature at the turbocharger's compressor inlet.
*   `feedback`: A generic feedback signal, likely from other control loops or state machines.
*   `C_FLOW_VOL_CHA_UP_RED_MAX`: A constant representing reduced maximum volumetric flow at the turbocharger compressor inlet.
*   `C_TIA_ABSV_CHA_UP_REF`: A reference value for absolute temperature at the turbocharger compressor inlet.

## Outputs
The system produces the following outputs (blue blocks):
*   `EFF_VOL_SLOP_CMPR`: Compressor-specific volumetric efficiency slope.
*   `EFF_VOL_OFS_CMPR`: Compressor-specific volumetric efficiency offset.
*   `PRS_LOSS_ICO_MAF_KGH_MAX`: Pressure loss across the intercooler/compressor based on maximum mass air flow and exhaust gas enthalpy.
*   `FLOW_VOL_CHA_UP_REL_PUT_MAX`: Relative volumetric flow at the compressor inlet at maximum pressure.
*   `PQ_CHA_PUT_MAX_GRD`: Gradient of the pressure-flow characteristic at maximum compressor pressure.
*   `PQ_CHA_PUT_MAX`: Maximum pressure-flow product at the compressor.
*   `PQ_CHA_DIF_PUT_MAX`: Differential pressure-flow product at maximum compressor pressure.
*   `FLOW_VOL_CHA_UP_REL_PUT_BAS`: Relative volumetric flow at the compressor inlet at base pressure.
*   `N_TCHA_PUT_MAX`: Maximum turbocharger speed for a given pressure.
*   `PUT_MAX_N_TCHA_MAX`: Maximum pressure related to maximum turbocharger speed.
*   `PUT_MAX_TCHA_PROT`: Maximum pressure for turbocharger protection.

## Logic Flow

The logical flow of Figure 10.15.4 proceeds in several stages:

1.  **Maximum Possible Mass Air Flow Calculation (`MAF_KGH_CMPR_SP_MAX_Intermediate`):**
    *   `PUT_SP` is multiplied by `C_FAC_PUT_SP_MAF_CHA_SP` (V.6.4 block) to derive a raw mass flow from engine load.

    *   The two intermediate results from the above steps are multiplied (V.6.7 block) to produce `MAF_KGH_CMPR_SP_MAX_Intermediate`, representing the maximum possible mass flow for the charger based on power and volumetric efficiency.

2.  **Final Mass Air Flow Setpoint Determination (`MAF_KGH_CMPR_SP`):**
    *   The `MAF_KGH_CMPR_SP_MAX_Intermediate` is compared with `MAF_KGH_SP_ENG_TCHA` (the engine's requested mass flow) using a `min` block (V.6.3).
    *   The smaller of these two values is selected as the final `MAF_KGH_CMPR_SP`, which is the mass air flow setpoint for the charger compressor.

3.  **Intermediate Charger Pressure Calculation (Fading Function for `PRS_CHA_UP_CLC`):**
    *   `IP_FAC_PRS_CHA_UP_SP` is fed into a 1D lookup table (V.7.3) to generate an `IP_val`. This `IP_val` acts as a blending factor.

3.  **Intermediate Charger Pressure Calculation (Fading Function for `PRS_CHA_UP_CLC`):**
    *   `IP_FAC_PRS_CHA_UP_SP` is fed into a 1D lookup table (V.7.3) to generate an `IP_val`. This `IP_val` acts as a blending factor.
    *   `IP_val` (as 'F') is used in a "FADING A*(1-F)+B*F" block (V.7.7). The inputs 'A' and 'B' are `PRS_AIC_DOWN_MAX` and `PRS_CHA_UP_MV` respectively. This block smoothly blends between the two pressure values based on the `IP_val` factor.
    *   The output of this fading block is `PRS_CHA_UP_CLC` (and `PRS_CHA_UP_SP_CLC`, which appears to be identical to `PRS_CHA_UP_CLC` based on the diagram).

4.  **Final Charger Pressure Setpoint (`PRS_CHA_UP_SP`):**
    *   A conditional block (V.6.0) selects between `LC_PRS_CHA_UP_SP_AS` and `C_PRS_CHA_UP_SP_AS`. The specific condition for this selection is not explicitly shown in the diagram.
    *   The selected pressure value is then added to `PRS_CHA_UP_CLC` (V.5.2 block).
    *   This sum is passed through a gain block (V.6.1) to produce the final `PRS_CHA_UP_SP`, the charger upstream pressure setpoint.

5.  **Charger Air Density Setpoint Calculation (`RHO_CHA_UP_SP`):**
    *   The absolute temperature `TIA_ABSV_CHA_UP` is divided by a constant value of 287 (V.6.4 block). This likely accounts for unit conversion or a gas constant.
    *   This result is then multiplied by the calculated `PRS_CHA_UP_SP` (V.6.7 block).
    *   Finally, this product is divided by a constant value of 100 (V.6.4 block) to yield `RHO_CHA_UP_SP`, the charger upstream air density setpoint. This calculation effectively uses a simplified form of the ideal gas law (Density = Pressure / (R * Temperature)).

## Function

The primary function of this Simulink diagram is to calculate and output a composite **turbocharger protection state** (`STATE_TCHA_PROT`) as a bitmask (an integer where each set bit corresponds to an active protection condition). It aggregates various conditions related to temporary and permanent torque limitations, intake air temperature, turbocharger speed, charger pressure, and other system-defined protection flags to provide a comprehensive status of turbocharger protection.

## Inputs

The diagram takes the following inputs:

1.  **`TQI_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX`**: Torque setpoint derived from an intake air temperature threshold for the turbocharger.
2.  **`phys_max`**: A general physical maximum limit or reference value, used in several comparisons.
3.  **`PUT_SP`**: Pump output target speed.
4.  **`PUT_SP_TOL`**: A tolerance or threshold value for the pump output target speed.
5.  **`TQI_N_TCHA_MAX`**: Torque setpoint derived from the maximum permissible turbocharger speed.
6.  **`LV_TIA_THR_TCHA_MAX_PROT`**: Latch or flag indicating active intake air temperature threshold protection for the turbocharger.
7.  **`LV_TCHA_PROT_ACT_CUS`**: Latch or flag indicating active customer-specific turbocharger protection.
8.  **`LV_N_TCHA_PROT`**: Latch or flag indicating active turbocharger speed protection.
9.  **`LV_TCHA_PROT_ACT_BPA`**: Latch or flag indicating active BPA (likely Bosch Powertrain or specific internal standard) related turbocharger protection.
10. **`LV_TEG_MAX_TCHA_DEAC`**: Latch or flag indicating a deactivation status related to maximum exhaust gas temperature protection for the turbocharger.

## Outputs

1.  **`STATE_TCHA_PROT`**: An integer value representing a bitmask. Each set bit in this integer indicates that a corresponding turbocharger protection condition is active.

## Logic Flow

The system evaluates a series of conditions. For each condition that is met, a specific power-of-2 value (corresponding to a unique bit position) is generated. These generated values are then summed up (logically ORed) to form the final `STATE_TCHA_PROT` bitmask. The `X` blocks in the diagram act as conditional pass-throughs, meaning they output the associated bit value if their input comparison is true, otherwise, they output zero. The `+-` blocks perform an aggregation (summation, acting as a bitwise OR for distinct powers of 2).
